Award.AwardTitle: The Economic Effects of Caring for Adult Family Members

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores the effects of caring for adult family members on caregivers' economic well-being. In the US, nearly one in four people care for an adult family member, partner, or friend, and the number is expected to rise. Research has yielded a wealth of information on the health outcomes of providing care, but we know less about the economic ramifications of providing care.

Drawing on nationally-representative, longitudinal data from the Health and Retirement Study, the project answers the following questions: How does caring for an elderly family member - a spouse or elderly parent - affect caregivers' employment decisions, earnings, savings, and wealth? Do the effects differ for men and women, and what are the sources of such differences? Do these different experiences have different effects on women's and men's employment decisions and economic outcomes? Do the effects differ by socioeconomic status? Do those with fewer resources, for example, take more time off from work and pay larger earnings penalties? There are a range of possible responses to caregiving dilemmas. This project explores these choices and their economic ramifications.

The findings from this project enhance our understanding work, family, and aging. Insights gained through this project could aid in understanding how to provide support for caregivers and their care recipients. The project also includes graduate and undergraduate students in all phases of the research, which helps to produce the next generation of scientists and citizens who can meet the needs of our 21st century aging society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nearly one in four U.S. adults care for an aging family member or friend, and this number is only expected to rise. The market value of care, or the cost of replacing all unpaid care with paid care, exceeds federal and state Medicaid spending. Caregiving responsibilities often arise during the peak of women's and men's careers, and many caregivers face a series of complicated and costly decisions. Many studies have focused on the adverse health effects associated with caregiving, but fewer studies have focused on the economic implications. This project analyzed nationally representative data from the Health and Retirement Study and investigated the relationships among elderly caregiving, women's and men's employment experiences, and their economic outcomes. The results were presented at professional conferences, published in peer-reviewed journals and research reports, and disseminated to non-academic audiences.

The first set of results focused on spousal caregiving, employment, and aging. Spouses often serve as the primary caregivers to their ill or disabled partners. Studies have shown that men receive more care from their wives than vice versa, but few studies have focused on how the gender gap in care varies across the later life course. The results from this NSF-funded research indicated that the gender gap in spousal care was larger among those in middle age (50-65) than it was among those in older age. In other words, as women and men aged, the gender gap decreased, primarily because men left full-time work and increased the amount of time that they spent caring for their wives. As women's and men's employment hours and time to care for each other converged, their time spent in spousal care also converged. These results focus our attention on changes in women's and men's caregiving experiences as they move from midlife into older age.

The second set of results from this NSF-funded research looked at the associations among depression, paid work, and spousal caregiving. The analyses indicated that for women, part-time work attenuated the depressive effect of spousal caregiving, whereas for men, part-time work exacerbated it. In other words, working while caring for a spouse was beneficial for women's mental health but detrimental to men's mental health. Coworkers may provide female caregivers emotional support, comfort, and sympathy as well as instrumental support, such as help sifting through information and resources. Work may also provide female caregivers with a helpful distraction from the challenges of family life.

The third set of results from this NSF-funded research examined the caregiving wage penalty for those who were between the ages of 50 and 64. Two cohorts were compared--one born between 1948 and 1953 (the so-called Early Baby Boomers) and another born between 1931 and 1941. Both women and men in the Baby Boom cohort spent more time caring for their elderly parents than women and men in the earlier generation. All else equal, elderly caregiving was associated with a five percent reduction in women's hourly wages, and this wage penalty did not differ between the two cohorts. Moreover, despite a substantial increase in Baby Boom men's provision of care to their elderly parents, they did not pay a wage penalty for parental caregiving.

In addition to these important research results, the NSF grant also facilitated the inclusion of undergraduate and graduate students in all phases of the research, which helped prepare them for their own research careers. The PI will continue to mentor students, publish studies from this research, and disseminate results that transform our understanding of work, family, and aging.
